p: Despite the importance of the M2 functions, it is not an essential protein for influenza A virus. In laboratory practice, so-called “M2 null” viruses have been obtained by various modifications of stop codons [ 13, 48, 131]. All of these viruses were viable but had a reduced replication level [ 13, 48, 116, 131, 136, 137]. Moreover, an M2-deficient single replication (M2SR) virus has been generated and evaluated as a possible candidate for live influenza vaccine. The M2SR vaccine was able to infect cells and express all viral proteins except M2, without generating progeny virus [ 103]. This vaccine platform proved efficient in protecting animals (mice and ferrets) against heterologous/heterosubtypic influenza virus infections [ 39, 40], and is now undergoing phase I clinical trials (clinicaltrials.gov NCT03553940; NCT02822105).
